pros: Living where I live, I would have made $30,000 less to do this job remotely or in person. My job was fully remote, great benefits, they teach you how to do everything.
cons: Micromanagement and there is a very high turnover rate.

pros: Company is flexible and supports a good cause Essential to helping support programs that would otherwise not be funded Good work life balance Great 203b contribution!
cons: HR can be very slow to respond and not always have a real answer Health insurance is costly, especially if you are insuring a spouse or child and there is only one company option No structure for advancement within current position. You will have to move to another job if you want a raise.

pros: I am inspired by my co-workers and our collaborators everyday. In my role, I am well supported by our administrative personnel. Working here also gives me a wider reach in public health. The flat style of this organization makes me feel like I’m directly contributing to all decisions. I love that aspect.
cons: It’s a flat organization at the moment, which doesn’t provide a lot of positions to promote into. Working remotely also means not all interactions can be as organic as working in person. However, we have a couple of channels to have more “human” interactions with each other. And the leadership actually listens to our suggestions.

review_title: A good company to work for
job_title: Community Outreach Worker in Houston, TX
pros: This company is one of the best I have worked for in regards to the benefits and care they give to employees.
cons: Although you are a full time employee with the CDC Foundation, you are to work with the city you live in, such as a city or county health department.

job_title: Contract Tracing Supervisor in Atlanta, GA
pros: Fully remote, great team, better pay and benefits that state employees
cons: The job depended on the place you were contracted out too, some people had good experiences and others did not.

pros: - lots of opportunities for professional development - opportunity to contribute to emergency response work - many opportunities for remote work
cons: - mostly short-term contract positions

pros: If the positions weren't contract jobs, I'd work here forever. Great management, excellent culture and great mission.
cons: I wish there were jobs that weren't contracts

review_title: Good benefits; poor communication of extensions for contract work
pros: Great health benefits, good PTO, and generally good work-life balance.
cons: If you are in a contracted position, you may only get updated on your status days before the contract is set to end. Could put you in a precarious spot.

pros: Awesome, positive group of people to work with. From the top to the bottom, they communicate effectively, keep you updated as soon as they gain information as to milestones, goals, status, etc. Great income for positions held, they are about your mental health, great benefits, work from home.
cons: Federally funded, contract positions, may not last long.

pros: Excellent professional development opportunities, great work schedule, remote work
cons: A bit disconnected from other projects

pros: great pay and great work helping folks
cons: Most is contract work so you better hope ur contract renews

pros: Great public health initiatives and ethics.
cons: Problem personnel kept jobs despite documented history of behavior that required other employees to leave.

review_title: The job isn't what it seems
pros: It's a remote job, so there is no commute Not a difficult job
cons: Your CDC Foundation manager has little to no authority over your site lead, who can get away with assigning work outside your role Untrustworthy management Little to no career development Incompetent coworkers

pros: Communication, flexible, understanding, caring, great staff

job_title: Communicable Disease Investigator in North Atlanta, GA

pros: Great work environment best job I have had.
cons: There are no cons at this time.

cons: time card is redundant very low vacation days only 11 /year

pros: Insight into learning how federal projects work.
cons: Huge learning curve for really low pay.

pros: Great opportunity to gain public health work experience
cons: Not fully organized to manage large pandemic emergency projects.

pros: Great place to gain public health experience.
cons: Management of field staff can be a bit disengaging

job_title: Covid-19 Case Investigator in Atlanta, GA

pros: Good salary Remote work option available
cons: Contract renewal promises is vague

review_title: Good benefits, good way to be quickly hired to contract to local programs`
job_title: Public Health Nurse in Baltimore, MD
pros: CDC Foundation contracted multiple workers to staff up state and local efforts to combat COVID-19, and it was a great way to quickly hire and cut through red tape to get programs up and running. The company did a great job of providing the hiring and HR support structure with minimal extra requirements of workers so they could focus on the demands of their contracting organization
cons: The salary offered to people during this program was subject to approval by the contracting organization, so the salary I received was not as competitive as it could have been for my experience, education and responsibilities of the job.

pros: No Micro Managing, Flexibility, Decent pay
cons: Work life balance, Not Supportive, No Room growth

review_title: Great place to work as public health professional
pros: Flexible schedule & positive environment
cons: Contract based position that ends within a year

pros: This is a wonderful place to work
cons: All remote, difficult onboarding process

review_title: Great organization to be a part of!
pros: Supportive work environment, great pay, good benefits, excellent work/life balance, I feel valued as an employee and person
cons: None significant enough to mention

review_title: Good pay but a pain to deal with
pros: Pay is great, and the retirement match is the best I've ever seen.
cons: Communication about contract extensions is next to non-existent, and sometimes crucial paperwork isn't distributed until the very last minute, leading to undue stress. Supervisors can be a bit all over the place as well.

pros: -Kind and respectful staff - Senior management really cares about workers -Salary and benefits are beyond excellent - company communicates very well
cons: For the 1st time in my entire 15 yrs professional career i have no cons to state for a company.

pros:
Lots of training recourses to take advantage of. 
Decent Health Insurance and 401K Matching 
Friendly Supervisors..
Work/life balance is good.
cons:
-Grant Funded positions end and they do not move people to new positions. 
-Other benefits (besides Health and 401K are lacking).
-I wouldn't recommend to a friend only b/c it's a lot to go through with regards to on-boarding and training only to have to look again for another position within a matter of months. 
-Also, they took forever getting me started. I first interviewed 6 mos. prior to starting.

review_title: One of the best jobs I have ever had
job_title: Regional Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: Great work environment and meaningful success in projects.
cons: A little unorganized but it is to be expected from Emergency Response Programs

review_title: Excellent benefits, everything else depends on your jurisdiction
pros: Salary above local market Excellent retirement matching Thoughtful leadership Helpful support staff in HR
cons: Short COVID contract Terrible messaging around layoffs

review_title: Can be rewarding, but contract is limited
pros: Projects can be enticing. Rewarding work as it makes an impact on the public
cons: Role is very dependent on what government contract you are assigned to and being on contract can be nerve wracking as role is not stable.

review_title: Disorganized, poor communication, and general lack of respect for contract employees
pros:
average pay
average benefits
not a challenging work
cons: As a contract employee, a majority of our contracts were supposed to be ended in June. There have been multiple notices regarding contract changes, and even some ending BEFORE the agreed upon date. Management refuses to give any clarity around the situation, but keeps expecting employees to plan for work into the future. Additionally, management seems to be on a weird power trip, aggressively enforcing policies without answering questions regarding the policy or even following the policy themselves. We have been struggling with finding work activities since the lull in the pandemic and no one has made any real effort to remedy it.

pros: work from home, good salary and 401k matching
cons: contract that could last months only, no job security

pros: Although it was remote, the CDC foundation did a great job engaging all of their members. The position was flexible, challenging, and rewarding.
cons: The position was short term and had limited potential for growth.

job_title: Prefer Not to Answer in Atlanta, GA
pros: Great Organization Flexible remote working options Great senior leadership Measurable impact Great 403B match
cons: Only two weeks' vacation Expensive healthcare coverage

pros: Great employer. Great employer. Great employer.
cons: None none none none none

review_title: Lack of transparency and weak leadership
pros: Very good and cheap benefits; working here contributes to PSLF program; great WFH flexibility depending on your locale
cons: Lack of transparency about anything and everything; HR is composed of ghosts you can’t pin down; regional leadership know very little about the prospects of your work; general leadership seems to not appreciate the rich workforce they’ve built and are quick to ditch them

pros: This position was remote so there was no commute involved.
cons: Very frustrating. couldn't even handle the onboarding. Most of my coworkers were incompetent.

pros: Good benefits, higher than average pay, supportive supervisors

pros: Good pay, great benefits, great work-life balance, caring management.

review_title: Excellent opportunity for a retired professional to help out during COVID-19
pros: Entirely remote, meaningful, part timework that was both interesting and challenging.
cons: I had a direct manager at CDC Foundation but as a member of their field staff I was on assignment to the PA Department of Health where there was also a manager and line of management. The managers were very different - CDC Foundation management was much better. Compensation was low. Although not much in the way of qualifications were required, most of us in the job were highly qualified.

pros: Great benefits, pay, and coworkers!
cons: had some problems figuring out mileage reimbursement for long-distance trips.

pros: Excellent benefits, autonomy, professional connections, working for positive change in public health

pros: great work being done. I enjoyed my time.

job_title: Public Health Nurse in Chicago, IL
pros: Everyone is nice, respectful, and encouraging. Nice pay.
cons: There is no real oversight. No one in leadership knows what they are doing. Leadership talks as if they know what is going on but nothing is really getting done. You are treated like an expert in the field and you really do not have the proper training.

review_title: Best company I have ever served with
pros: Firstly, the work they do is extremely important. As far as I am aware they treat all their employees with respect, privacy and encouragement. If you ever have something going on in your life everyone from your direct supervisor up to the highest level will bend over backwards to assist you.
cons: They do work on grants. So many of the positions are contract (which could be extended). There are a few full time positions, but there seems to be a lot of moving around. However, once you are in the door and do a good job you can continue on and up many times over. I jumped from a medium wage job to a big girl huge salary:)

pros: CDC Foundation is a great, high-energy organization!

review_title: Some pros for first time job hunters
pros: The retirement contribution is awesome!
cons:
No equitable or even well-written HR policies leads to employee confusion when it comes to benefits, pay increases, travel, and many work policies in general. HR department is significantly lacking. Questions often go ignored unless they are pressed several times and often answers are nebulous. 
There is no clear way to move up without finding another job that pays higher within the company, or leave altogether.

pros: Fabulous benefits. Great personal responsibility and freedom

pros: Average salary easy application process

Then they pushed it up again to be immediately. As well, had 3 different supervisors in 3 weeks. The staff rotates too quickly. HR staff is very rude. The supervisors are inexperienced and arrogant.

pros:
*Mission driven organization, employees are motivated by intrinsic rewards. You can tell employees want to make a positive difference. 
*403B benefits 
*The executive team (COO) / President is approachable and willing to listen 
*close proximity to CDC 
*opportunity to work on important grant related work or private partnerships
cons:
*Micromanagement persists. Managers are not trusted to make decisions, each decision needs to be approved before moving forward. This slows down the grant work. 
*Lack of communication between departments can be frustrating. 
*Issues are not resolved, instead they fester into larger organizational problems. 
*There are equitable issues with compensation. 
*The COO is doing her very best to turn the organization around, however, she continues to listen to the wrong advisors.

review_title: Understand who you will be working with.
pros: Some cool initiatives and work with CDC or global partners.  Your position may not take your education into consideration and some working groups are more silo'd than others.  If you get the right project with the right boss, it may be easier.
cons: Silos.  Sometimes the work seems like a pass-through for funding CDC.  Upper management is quite a closed group, not to be challenged.
